¦ 𓄙

Todo: merge RTL right-to-left mirrored rotated reversed

Wanderwords and Kulturwords often exhibit extended matches with permuted consonants.
While permutations themselves can simply be genetic mutations of words, something deeper seems to go on.
One reason for perfectly reversed orthography might be that during the foundation period of writing the reading order of phrases and compound signs was not set in stone. Between cultures there might have been confusion between left to right and right to left readings.

See rotated / permuted words

article as orthocul orthographic little orientation a'rotation markers see ma

𒉆 nam -ment reverse

ma acted as a reverse reading direction marker :
𒋢 kuš կաշ kaši cushion reverse:
𒋢 mašku[n] 𓄟𓂓𓄛 skin մաշկ mašk مَسْك mask 𐎶𐏁𐎣𐎠 mussuck µ.Sack 𓎅
Note how both forms are in use in Armenian

Slightly different reversion:
𓄟𓂓𓄛 चर्म carmis < dermis 𓄛 @ Moschus μόσχος musketeer

Notably in Sumerian the micro etymology of compound characters reads right to left, even though the general reading direction is the opposite! Of the many examples here are some:

YA 𒅀 = Y+A 𒄿+𒀀 < MY 𒀀 mu 𒄿 y

𒍪𒀊 ZU.AB Abzu abyss
𒊑𒅆 IKI.RI ⲕⲁⲣⲁ kara krye kokë ϫⲁϫ čač cephal < IKI.paRI корта korta ϫⲱ čōv < ⲕⲉⲫⲁⲗⲏ (head)
𒀭𒂗𒍪 SU.EN Sîn can candra
𒈗 = 𒃲 + 𒇽 Gal+lu Gallu / Lugal (crowned king)
TIM 𒁴 totem with 𒈨 'me' on the right end
US 𒊻 = 𒄷𒊺 ᵍHU-ŠE goose 𓅾
MAŠ2 𒈧 Dam+mas maš𒈦 Dammwild deer
𒈗 Legal Lugal Regent = 𒃲 GAL < great 𒇽 LÚ Leute : King(s), Gallier

𓆰 cannabis κάνναβος 𒋆𒄣𒌦𒈾𒁍 qunnapu ܩܢܦܐ qnpʾ قِنَّب qinnab կանեփ kanepʿ kenevir
भाङ्ग (bhāṅga) بنگ (bang), the "reversed" forms of it (due to a taboo)

sometimes permuted reverse forms are both attested in the same language:

𓌦 𓏏 𓐍 𓏴 𓀜 | weave | 𒋳 TUKU тукырга tuqırga توقۇماق toqumaq токуу toquu Tuch textile tech

Many words are cognate if they are read right to left
𓊪 𓂧 𓋴 𓂾 podes𓃀stamp
𓇋 𓏏 𓆑 (f)atav | father
𓈙 𓏏 𓍃 𓅓 𓅯 𓀁||hostility| ال𓅯 عداوة
...
𓊿 Amun Narmer?
𓅞 Toth teacher immutable

In a time when reading order was not settled these variants might have arisen via errors 'lost in translation', puns, consonant permutations or (less likely) : coincidence.

According to Wikipedia Some reversed forms may have arisen from taboos
